text:
Question for the community here. Someone I know that works at a SaaS company recently made a comment that I very respectfully but also strongly disagreed with. That being said, given that I am an agency owner, I’m obviously a bit biased.

The comment was along the lines of _any person would choose a content role at a company/SaaS in this case over working at an agency if they had the choice_.

I don’t agree that this is the case. At least from those I already know (too small of a sample size) which were presented with the choice of working for a single 7-figure software company (that oftentimes doesn’t value their work) or agency that works with a number of 7-figure+ software company, they love having the opportunity to see the direct impact of their work, working alongside other talented marketers and being well-compensated all while not having to deal with internal company politics – which altogether they wouldn’t necessarily have the opportunity to do otherwise.

*Would you prefer to work with a company over an agency if you had the choice and everything else was virtually the same?* 

Also worth adding that (also based on a limited sample size), content hires @ agencies last longer than at individual companies because they’re more than willing to put in the effort needed to train them rather than companies which don’t have the expertise and will blame/replace employees when they aren’t getting results.

Would you prefer to work with a company over an agency if you had the choice and everything else was virtually the same?

Also worth adding that (also based on a limited sample size), content hires @ agencies last longer than at individual companies because they’re more than willing to put in the effort needed to train them rather than companies which don’t have the expertise and will blame/replace employees when they aren’t getting results.

text: I think company over agency applies when people want to share their work and grow their own personal brand. If you're producing agency work for clients with no byline, I'd imagine you're tied to that kind of work for a long time.

text:
From a personal POV, I love working for various SaaS companies as I get to be the face of the blog and grow my own rep this way.

From here, I gain my own freelance clients, expand my portfolio, and rarely need to look for work.

Flip that to working in agency and I *imagine* I'd do the same work, get less credit, and not grow as an individual as rapidly.

text:
> Flip that to working in agency and I *imagine* I’d do the same work, get less credit, and not grow as an individual as rapidly.
Now you’re comparing freelancer vs. agency. Freelancing definitely has its advantages over working for an agency. That being said, some of the best writers/content marketers I know just don’t want to be involved in dealing with clients, billing, paying taxes for an LLC etc. and all the BS stuff that only business owners should worry about.

They want to focus on doing the work and getting the results. Also, in the right agency everyone gets even more credit than the founder/CEO of the agency does for the work produced :slightly_smiling_face:

text:
amazing question

before I joined Animalz, I was convinced that moving from agency -> startup was the best choice for me. I wanted more ownership over my work, a self-esteem boost from joining a "big name" company, and a pay increase

I've been lucky to get all of those apparent "startup benefits" from working at an agency - I've worked with Google/Zendesk/Wistia/etc., our agency is pretty well known, and my starting salary at Animalz was greater than my starting salary at the startup (even though I was marketing hire #2 and they had raised $25MM)

so I think:

• the grass is always greener. both agencies and startups have major headaches at times (i.e. being a <https://www.animalz.co/blog/content-team-of-one/|solo marketer is tricky>)
• there are great startups and bad startups, great agencies and bad agencies. it pays to be very selective, regardless of which path you take
• why not try both? a la <@UJG9WTEKG> article on <https://superpath.co/blog/expand-and-contract|career hopping>

<@UJ3K7N8GJ> 100% – I think you hit the nail on the head. It’s so dependent on the agency and on the company itself that you really can’t make a general comparison that applies across the board or even in over 80% of situations :+1:

And then, as you said, it also depends on the person which is why career hopping is potentially a good move if you’re not fully satisfied where you currently are…

elements.text: 100% – I think you hit the nail on the head. It’s so dependent on the agency and on the company itself that you really can’t make a general comparison that applies across the board or even in over 80% of situations

text:
one concrete difference that I think actually plays in favour of agencies: the #1 complaint I've heard from startup marketers is not having peers to help develop their skills - editors, other writers, people that care as much about your craft as you do

it's really easy to reach a local maxima of skill when you're the only content person in a company.

a good agency is _theoretically_ packed full of people with the same interest. I became MUCH better at my job after moving from a team of two content marketers to a team of 50+

you _can_ solve that at a startup if the content team gets big enough, but most co's we talk to have very lean marketing teams, full stop

text:
Agree it's kind of a silly statement. There are very good reasons to go agency vs. in-house at different points of your career.

The company I'm with now started as an analytics consultancy using an open source product. Today software sales on the commercial product outpace consulting revenue, but we still do some consulting work. Folks on that team are making the same choice -- in-house data team or agency? Doing 1-2 years at a well-respected agency doing innovative work is a phenomenal career accelerator. We've had people do a few years on the team and then move into incredibly ambitious data roles at big name companies.

If you want to go deep on a specific skill set there is nothing like joining an agency who is known for that thing.

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

text: I think there are a lot of bad agencies out there and that reflects on people's perceptions of all agencies. Toronto is a very traditional ad agency city, for example, most of which have gotten into content marketing in the last 5-10 years, and they pay the bare minimum, work people to the bone, and have very little room for advancement. People burn out before they can move up. I know tons of content marketers who started in those agency environments and went on to work in-house and had an infinitely better experience. So it was probably someone like that, which is fair if that was your experience.

elements.text: I think there are a lot of bad agencies out there and that reflects on people's perceptions of all agencies. People burn out before they can move up. I know tons of content marketers who started in those agency environments and went on to work in-house and had an infinitely better experience. So it was probably someone like that, which is fair if that was your experience.

text:
> having the opportunity to see the direct impact of their work
Personally, this is the biggest differentiator for me. I actually feel like this works better in the favor of working in-house because you’re not restricted by whatever contract the agency has with the client company. Having said that, I’ve _only_ ever worked at agencies and I definitely get that “grass is greener” syndrome (despite having generally positive experiences at agencies). I _imagine_ you would get more of a voice and can have a more direct impact on the company and see its effects in other areas/departments of the company.
But I agree with what others have said here, there’s good/bad on both sides and there’s nothing wrong with trying both sides. Generalizing to this extent is kinda silly.

text: My days of salaried work for other people are pretty far in my rearview mirror, but, all else being equal, I'd have preferred agency jobs (in any discipline) to standard jobs.  I was prone to getting bored and job hopping, and agency work basically lets you do that, but without the hassle and inefficiency of a job hunt.

text: As an aside, if someone starts a premise with "_any_ person would..." I'm guessing they don't have a lot of experience polling people for actual data.  Poll enough people and you'll find the counter-example, however off-the-wall it may seem.  "Everyone holds {opinion}," in my experience, usually translates to "I hold {opinion}."

text:
It's a valid point that you may not have peers, but what if you get into a startup that's willing to invest and you build a team of freelancers? That's what happened to me. Not only that I managed to get management to invest in writers, editors, linkbuildiners, CRO experts to work together with me, I managed to also get them very attached to the startup idea and product.

My point is, startup/profitable company/agency - you're always going to look for people who are going to help you with growth.

text: I’ve only ever worked on the company side as content marketer, but I can say that because I have a tendency to get bored writing about the same industry, agency life appeals to me. Before I discovered content marketing, my first two jobs were with with agencies (albeit doing event planning/sponsorship activation), but I’ve always enjoyed the diversity of clients that come with an agency. I think the preference of company versus agency is highly dependent on the person.

text:
this is one of the best convos i’ve ever seen in this group, so much good stuff.
in my own career, i went agency -> in-house -> agency -> in-house -> agency. each had it’s benefits. i can say with 100% certainty that i learned more and grew faster at agencies. it’s not even close. i loved working in-house because of the focus on a single business. that taught me a whole new set of skills.
for me personally, bouncing back and forth provided a constant set of new challenges to work and regular pay increases.
animalz pays well and has clear paths to promotions and raises. the other agency i worked for didn’t…i didn’t get a raise or even a performance review in the 2.5 years i worked there!

text:
Similar to Jimmy, I went agency -> in-house -> agency -> in-house -> agency -> in-house. I feel like there are a ton of variables at play and making any kind of blanket statement is a dicey call at best.

That said, I do think it's important to try both sides, and try a variety of company sizes, until you find the right fit.

text: Hey all! I'm currently in the process of development a Google Analytics/Google Data Studio report for measuring content success. Appreciate any help or advice!

text:
:wave::skin-tone-4: all,

I've started writing more content, and I always find myself staring at a blank page or having a jumbled mess of a brain dump.

I've been in SEO for almost a decade, but I've always produced the strategy and briefs behind the content, so my content production skills are average.

How do I get past what I assume is a mental block?

I can talk about these topics/ideas all day, but the moment I sit down to write, it all goes out the window.  I don't know if it's a lack of confidence or my dislike for writing, maybe both?

Any tips?

elements.text:
all,

I've started writing more content, and I always find myself staring at a blank page or having a jumbled mess of a brain dump.

I've been in SEO for almost a decade, but I've always produced the strategy and briefs behind the content, so my content production skills are average.

How do I get past what I assume is a mental block?

I can talk about these topics/ideas all day, but the moment I sit down to write, it all goes out the window.  I don't know if it's a lack of confidence or my dislike for writing, maybe both?

Any tips?

text:
I've often found that when i get writers block it means i'm not ready to write something yet. either i dont know what i'm going to write or i don't know enough about it.

Try either building an outline or, if you already have one, starting from a part of the article you're confident writing

elements.text:
I've often found that when i get writers block it means i'm not ready to write something yet. either i dont know what i'm going to write or i don't know enough about it.

Try either building an outline or, if you already have one, starting from a part of the article you're confident writing

text: if all else fails i read more about the topic and what other people are saying to see if it inspires me to write something new

elements.text: if all else fails i read more about the topic and what other people are saying to see if it inspires me to write something new

elements.text:
Thanks for feedback!

Yeah, I think that's my main roadblock.  I'm never ready to write.

For example, I'm currently writing about a topic I have a deep understanding of, and I'm still running into the same roadblock.

text: yeah, you probably need to boil it down to a specific question you're trying to answer. do you have a content calendar?

text: became <https://superpath.co/blog/say-yes-to-start-your-career-say-no-to-advance-it>

attachments.title: Say "Yes" to Start Your Career, Say "No" to Advance It - Superpath
attachments.text: Career development is confusing for everyone, but perhaps more so for content marketers. There is no clear career path—most of us can only see 1-2 years ahead in our careers, and we're usually wrong anyway. This is actually a really good thing. In How Will You Measure Your Life?, Clay Christensen describes Walmart founder Sam Walton's plans to open his second store in Memphis, Tenn., thinking that a presence in a large city would offer more opportunities for growth. But his plans never came to

text: Another trick I use is dictation. Take a voice recorder (ideally not your phone) with you on a walk and just ramble away. ~20 mins is equivalent to about 1000 words. Then run it through Dragon or another transcription app. You'll end up rewriting most of it — but at least you won't have to face the terror of the blank screen.

elements.text: Another trick I use is dictation. Take a voice recorder (ideally not your phone) with you on a walk and just ramble away. ~20 mins is equivalent to about 1000 words. Then run it through Dragon or another transcription app. You'll end up rewriting most of it — but at least you won't have to face the terror of the blank screen.

text:
^ Agreed. Other tactics I've found helpful:

• The Q&A. Write subheadings as a series of questions. I find it easier to write that way. Closer to what I'm doing now. Just dropping thoughts in a chat box. (So meta.)
• Frame it like a presentation. Imagine you're submitting a talk to a conference. What's the POV? What's the key argument? What are the takeaways/"learnings"?
• Riffing on the above: Do a slide deck first. Knock out the visual concepts and important points. Flesh it out from there. I've monologued to myself while out on walks or running errands.
• Listicles. Seriously. "The X things I believe about Y." Change the title afterwards, but it forces you to come up with the key points.

elements.text: ^ Agreed. Other tactics I've found helpful:
The Q&A. Write subheadings as a series of questions. I find it easier to write that way. Closer to what I'm doing now. Just dropping thoughts in a chat box. (So meta.)
Frame it like a presentation. Imagine you're submitting a talk to a conference. What's the POV? What's the key argument? What are the takeaways/"learnings"?
Riffing on the above: Do a slide deck first. Knock out the visual concepts and important points. Flesh it out from there. I've monologued to myself while out on walks or running errands.
Listicles. Seriously. "The X things I believe about Y." Change the title afterwards, but it forces you to come up with the key points.

text: aaron orendorff has a helluva template he uses. I saw the presentation Copyhackers. I think also did a guest post. Templates or frameworks are helpful. So are what I call archetypes. Sometimes you can just dig in and pull one of those out and match it with a topic. interviews and case studies are loaded types of articles

text: Have you looked into the Building A Second Brain methodology from Tiago Forte? I find the blank page really intimating so I try to build a research process that’s basically constantly rolling so I always have ideas, notes, and resources to start my next article. I haven’t looked at a truly blank page since.

elements.text: Have you looked into the Building A Second Brain methodology from Tiago Forte? I find the blank page really intimating so I try to build a research process that’s basically constantly rolling so I always have ideas, notes, and resources to start my next article. I haven’t looked at a truly blank page since.

text: I really believe in outlining as a way of breaking the idea down into parts and then tackling them individually. I never write from beginning to end (usually leave my intro and conclusion to last). But once you have all your subheadings and structure mapped you can usually think of them more-or-less as standalone pieces rather than seeing the piece as an overwhelming whole. It feels almost more like "assembling" than straight up creative writing this way. Bonus: Most people will read it this way too.

elements.text: I really believe in outlining as a way of breaking the idea down into parts and then tackling them individually. I never write from beginning to end (usually leave my intro and conclusion to last). But once you have all your subheadings and structure mapped you can usually think of them more-or-less as standalone pieces rather than seeing the piece as an overwhelming whole. It feels almost more like "assembling" than straight up creative writing this way. Bonus: Most people will read it this way too.

text: Also, I love playing with the outline "rearranging the furniture" before I get too far in the writing. It minimizes the editing on the other side when the outline is tight to start with.

elements.text: Also, I love playing with the outline "rearranging the furniture" before I get too far in the writing. It minimizes the editing on the other side when the outline is tight to start with.

text: How do you all create guardrails for the amount/type of follow-up questions you'll answer for a client after an engagement? I ask because to offer some support via Slack to my clients after an engagement, but it can't turn into free consulting. It should be more like follow-up questions, clarifications, that sort of thing. Does anyone have any great ideas for creating and enforcing ground rules?

text: +1 for <@U010GTFAFK9> . If you’re judged on SEO then google search console can give you an idea of where you’re heading (rankings etc). Social shares could work too but that’s a very dependent variable. Interested in hearing if people have others :slightly_smiling_face:
